column1: 19939`https://www.cityofchicago.org/content/dam/city/depts/water/supp_info/arcConRpt/2016construction/nov_2016/20161102_Diversey_Christiana_35w.pdf`Success`Success`2`2`Not a fillable PDF.`                    RE:   Water Main Replacement Project #0601102    November 2
column2: 2016   Dear Neighbor
column3: In coordination with Mayor Rahm Emanuel’s Building a New Chicago infrastructure investment  program
column5: I would like to provide you with information  about an upcoming water main construction project in your neighborhood.    By mid November 2016
column6: Department of Water Management (DWM) and NPL Construction Co.  crews will begin the work to install 3
column7: 098 feet of new 8-inch water main in W. Diversey Avenue
column8: from N. Kimball Avenue to N. Sacramento Avenue and N. Christiana Avenue
column9: from W. George Street  to W. Diversey Avenue. The old water main dates back to 1891
column10: and needs to be replaced.    If you would like to receive regular email updates about the progress of the project
column11: please go to  BuildingANewChicago.org to register for the WaterALERT program.  Simply enter your name
column12: email address and the project identification number at the top of this letter.   By signing up for the WaterALERT emails
column13: you will be notified as the project enters each new  construction phase – from our mobilization of equipment onto the site
column14: to the installation of new  pipes
column15: to the final restoration of the street.   When we are working in the street
column16: we may close or limit it to traffic for safety reasons
column17: but you will  always be able to reach your home or business.  Outside of working hours
column18: a travel lane will be left  open for local traffic only.    We will post our work area for “No Parking” as needed during work hours (generally 7am-4pm).   Parking outside of those hours will be allowed
column19: but cars will need to be moved by the start of the  next workday.  We will try to preserve as much parking space as possible.   We know that construction always involves inconveniences and noise. We will do everything  possible to maintain your quality of life throughout these projects
column20: and conducting ourselves as  good and thoughtful neighbors in the course of our presence on your street.    Should you have any questions or concerns
column21: you can either ask the construction foreman during the  project
column22: or call any of the following numbers:    •  24-Hour City Service and Information Line:  311  •  35th Ward Office: 773-887-3772  •  DWM Office of Public Affairs:  312-744-6635        Genwmnot03032016          Flushing after Your Service Line has been Connected to the New Water Main    When we switch over the services from the old main to the new water main
column23: we will interrupt water  service.  We give you 24-hour notice when this is to happen.  However
column24: in the event of an emergency  shutdown during construction
column25: we may not be able to give you prior warning.   Now that your old water main has been replaced and your water service has been connected to the  new water main
column26: it is important to flush your plumbing of any sediment
column28: including  any lead to maintain water quality.     Sediment
column30: including any lead may collect in the aerator screen located at the tip of  your faucets.  These screens should be removed prior to flushing.  (1) Please find the closest available tap (an outside  hose spigot
column31: laundry sink faucet or bathtub) to where  the water comes into the home that is not used for  drinking water. Fully open the cold water tap and let  the water run for at least 5 minutes.  Next flush any  other cold water faucets on that floor for at least 5  minutes.   (2)Move to the next highest floor and repeat.  (3) Move to additional floors in sequence and flush          any taps or faucets for at least 5 minutes.      If you have any questions or concerns about your water quality
column32: or if you would like your water  tested
column33: please call us at 311.  For additional advice and information visit  http://www.epa.gov/il/advice-chicago-residents-about-lead-drinking-water.   Routine Flushing  If your water line has been idle or stagnant for more than 6-hours
column34: it is advised that you flush for at  least 5 minutes to maintain water quality.  This may include flushing the toilet
column35: taking a shower and  doing laundry.     MeterSave  Lastly
column36: if you don’t already have one
column37: I ask you to consider the installation of a water meter in your  home to help you save money on your water bill.   For more information on this free program
column38: go to  www.metersave.org.   Thank you in advance for your patience and cooperation during this important infrastructure  improvement project.   Sincerely

column1: 20744`https://www.cityofchicago.org/content/dam/city/depts/bacp/publicvehicleinfo/publicchauffer/driversbillofrightsflyer20151229.pdf`Success`Success`1`1`Not a fillable PDF.`TAXICAB DRIVERS KNOW YOUR RIGHTS! !     Know the taxicab vehicle TIER and AGE of the taxicab you lease. For a list of approved taxicab vehicles classified by tier  number
column2: please visit www.cityofchicago.org/BACP.  “Vehicle Age” is the age of a vehicle computed by totaling the number of years in between and including both the calendar  year and the model year. (Examples: In the calendar year 2016
column3: a vehicle model year of 2016 = vehicle age of 1 year and a vehicle  model year of 2013 = vehicle age of 4 years.)           The following lease rate structures are effective pursuant to §9-112-230:  Tier 1 Vehicles (MPG ≥  36 OR CNG MPG ≥ 21)  12-Hour Daily  Maximum Lease  Rate  12-Hour Weekly  Maximum Lease  Rate  24-Hour Daily  Maximum Lease  Rate  24-Hour Weekly  Maximum Lease  Rate  Vehicle Age of 1 year or  less Vehicle Age of 2 years Vehicle Age 3 years or  greater  $72 per 12-hr shift  $504 per week   $99 per 24-hr shift  $693 per week  $71 per 12-hr shift  $497 per week  $95 per 24-hr shift  $665 per week  $59 per 12-hr shift  $413 per week  $85 per 24-hr shift  $595 per week  Tier 2 Vehicles (MPG ≥  25 but  ≤ 35 OR CNG  MPG ≤ 20)  12-Hour Daily  Maximum Lease  Rate  12-Hour Weekly  Maximum Lease  Rate  24-Hour Daily  Maximum Lease  Rate  24-Hour Weekly  Maximum Lease  Rate  Vehicle Age 1 year or  less Vehicle Age of 2 years Vehicle Age of 3 years  or greater   Tier 3 Vehicles (MPG ≤  24)  $69 per 12-hr shift  $483 per week  $93 per 24-hr shift  $651 per week  $59 per 12-hr shift  $413 per week  $85 per 24-hr shift  $595 per week   $54 per 12-hr shift  $363 per week  $78 per 24-hr shift  $539 per week  12-Hour Daily  Maximum Lease  Rate  12-Hour Weekly  Maximum Lease  Rate  24-Hour Daily  Maximum Lease  Rate  24-Hour Weekly  Maximum Lease  Rate  Any Vehicle Age  $54 per 12-hr shift  $363 per week  $78 per 24-hr shift  $539 per week  > In addition to the above
column6: lease agreements may include fees to recoup GTT & Accessibility  Fund fees paid by medallion licensees: (1) maximum of $2.50 for a 12-Hour Daily Lease; (2) maximum of $17.50 for  a 12-Hour Weekly Lease; (3) maximum of $5.00 for a 24-Hour Daily Lease; or (4) maximum of $35.00 for a 24-Hour  Weekly Lease.  The maximum per day a taxicab driver pays towards worker’s compensation insurance coverage is $4.50. Effective January 1
column8: the maximum a cab driver may be charged for credit card processing is 4%. You have the RIGHT to receive a completed signed lease agreement detailing the charges for the lease of a taxicab prior to the  delivery of a taxicab. Leases cannot be “chained” in order to charge a higher rate than the maximum lease caps. For example
column9: two consecutive 12- hour daily leases with the same driver cannot be higher than the maximum 24 hour lease rate for that taxicab vehicle. You have the RIGHT to a written receipt itemizing any and all expenses not included in the lease rate. You have the RIGHT to get paid for credit card transactions within ONE business day.  You have a RIGHT against retaliation from medallion owners
column11: and affiliations.  E-mail BACPPV@cityofchicago.org:  •	 •	  to sign up for information on the taxicab industry
column13: and other events in Chicago  to report if any of your RIGHTS have been violated.        6 1 0 2 1  .  . 1 . v  DEPARTMENT OF BUSINESS AFFAIRS AND CONSUMER PROTECTION PUBLIC VEHICLE OPERATIONS DIVISION 2350 W. Ogden

column2: 2017      RE:       Dear Neighbor
column3: In coordination with Mayor Rahm Emanuel’s “Building a New Chicago” infrastructure  improvement program
column5: I would like to provide you with  information about an upcoming sewer construction project in your neighborhood.     In mid to late March
column6: the Department of Water Management’s private contractor will begin  work to install a junction structure at the intersection of Central Avenue and 62nd Street.     During construction (about 6 weeks)
column7: the southbound lane of Central Avenue will be closed  (the northbound lane will remain open).  Traffic will be directed by a flagger. You will  always be able to reach your home or business.  Safety is always our first consideration.    We will post our work area for “No Parking” as needed during work hours (generally 7am- 4pm).  We are agreeable to parking outside of those hours
column8: but cars will need to be moved  by the start of the next workday.  We will try to preserve as much parking as possible.    We know that construction always involves inconveniences and noise. We will do  everything possible to maintain your quality of life throughout these projects
column9: and  conducting ourselves as good and thoughtful neighbors in the course of our presence on  your street.     Should you have any questions or concerns
column10: you can either ask the construction foreman  during the project
column11: or call any of the following numbers:       24-Hour Service and Information Line:  311    13th Ward Office: 773-581-8000    DWM Office of Public Affairs:  312-744-6635   Lastly
column12: if you don’t already have one
column13: I ask you to consider the installation of a water meter  in your home to help you save money on your water bill.   For more information on this free  program
column14: go to www.metersave.org.     Thank you in advance for your patience and cooperation during this important  infrastructure improvement project.          Sincerely

column1: 26147`https://www.cityofchicago.org/content/dam/city/depts/dhr/supp_info/JobSpecifications/JobSpecName/LATHER_4460.pdf`Success`Success`2`2`Not a fillable PDF.`Code:  4460  Operation and Construction Service  Building Maintenance and Operation Group  Masonry Trade Series       CLASS TITLE:  Lather    CHARACTERISTICS OF THE CLASS:  Under supervision
column2: performs skilled  lathing work
column3: creating and installing support backings of metal or  wood lath on which plaster or other gypsum materials are applied; and  performs related duties as required.      ESSENTIAL DUTIES:  Reads blueprints
column4: specifications and work orders to  assess existing structures and work required
column5: and to determine work  layout for job completion; ensures adequate supplies of tools
column6: equipment and materials needed to complete jobs are at work sites;  builds frameworks or furring and fastens securely to framing for  interior and exterior walls
column7: ceilings and building partitions; uses  power and hand tools to create and install support backings of wood or  metal lath or light iron resembling wire netting on which plaster or  other materials are applied
column8: and attaches to furring; cuts openings in  lath for heating and ventilation piping
column9: duct work and electrical  outlets; installs corner beads and wire mesh around beams to which  plaster is applied; installs solid or perforated gypsum board on  ceilings or walls; installs acoustical tile
column10: hangers for suspended  ceilings or metal studs for composition wallboard or lath; maintains  records of materials used; prepares work activity reports.    RELATED DUTIES:  Loads
column11: transports and unloads equipment and supplies;  cleans tools and work site after repairs; may assist in the  application of plaster to laths.     MINIMUM QUALIFICATIONS:    Training and Experience.  Labor registered lathing apprenticeship training program and  journeyman status
column12: or an equivalent combination of training and  experience.     Knowledge
column13: Abilities and Skill.  Good knowledge of the work methods  and techniques of the lathing trade.  Good knowledge of safety  practices and procedures.  Good knowledge of the tools
column14: equipment and  materials of the lathing trade.      Ability to read and interpret blueprints and specifications.  Physical  ability to use the tools and equipment of the trade.  Ability to  access work areas located above or below ground level.  Ability to  prepare work activity reports.   Successful completion of a US Department of   Code:  4460  Operation and Construction Service  Building Maintenance and Operation Group  Masonry Trade Series       CLASS TITLE:  Lather          (Cont'd)    Skill in assembling and installing metal or wood frameworks.  Skill in  the use of tools and equipment of the lathing trade.  Basic math  skills.  Basic oral and written communication skills.     Physical Requirements.  Ability to lift and carry supplies
column15: materials  and tools weighing up to 30 pounds frequently and up to 75 pounds  occasionally.     Working Conditions.  Unavoidable exposure to inclement weather and  extreme temperatures.     Equipment.  Standard tools and equipment of the trade including steel  squares
column17: and various power tools such as  screw guns and saws.          NOTE: While the list of essential duties is intended to be as inclusive   as possible
column18: there may be other duties which are essential  to particular positions within the class.                  November
column19: 2004  City of Chicago  Department of Personnel

column10: and third party  insurance administrators    •  Reviews and evaluates insurance proposals from brokers for pricing
column12: and adherence   to specifications    •  Prepares insurance price and cost analysis related to insurance policies   •  Negotiates insurance policy terms and conditions to obtain maximum coverages at the lowest   price    •  Reviews property

column1: 21557`https://www.cityofchicago.org/content/dam/city/depts/fss/supp_info/DV/NationalJusticeReports/helplinehistory.pdf`Success`Success`1`1`Not a fillable PDF.`  History    •   •     Help Line Operations   City of Chicago Domestic Violence Help Line   Background   In 1997
column2: Mayor Daley’s Domestic Violence Advocacy Coordinating Council  (DVACC) and the Mayor’s Office on Domestic Violence (MODV) completed its  Assessment of the Current Response to Domestic Violence in Chicago. Gaps in  the provision of services and the need for a central source for victim information
column3: resources
column4: and referral links were identified.   In 1998
column5: the City of Chicago Domestic Violence Help Line began operation. The  intent was to alleviate the frustrating and often tedious search for services by  victims and those who respond to victim’s request for help such as police officers.    •  The Illinois Domestic Violence Act of 1986 mandated the police department to  give a domestic violence referral to the victim in all domestic violence related  calls.  The Help Line gives officers a single phone number to access all domestic  violence services in Chicago. Giving the Help Line number is now mandatory  protocol for police officers.    •  Since its inception
column6: the Help Line is a public-private collaboration between the   City’s Mayor’s Office on Domestic Violence (MODV) and the Chicago  Metropolitan Battered Women’s Network (CMBWN)
column7: a private coalition of  domestic violence agencies.    •  The City’s Help Line operates 24 hours a day
column11: confidential service that functions as a clearinghouse for all  domestic violence services in the metropolitan area.    •  Victim Information and Referral Advocates (VIRAs)
column12: employed by the CMBWN   answer calls received at the Help Line and provide general domestic violence  information
column13: referral and linkage between victims and domestic violence  community based services and public responders.    •  VIRAs are trained domestic violence advocates who provide information and  options available for the victim to make her own informed decision about her  situation.   •  VIRAs collect basic information from each caller including demographics and   service needs (not victim identifying information). Call information recorded into  a database includes victim and abuser demographic information
column17: and the zip code of the caller.    •  Based on the service need the VIRA searches an up to date database containing   domestic violence service provider agency information.  Once a referral is  identified
column18: a direct three way phone link can be made between the Help Line  caller
column19: the VIRA and the community based service to ensure that callers get  connected directly to the program.  If the caller prefers or the agency is closed
column20: the  domestic violence agency’s phone number is offered.     •  MODV analyzes the administrative data for trends and gaps in service and   publishes annual reports including caller demographics and other highlights.

column6: ] in the City's [Department 1   You are [Senior Manager  and  an  attorney licensed to  practice in Illinois.  You are  interested in doing pro  bono legal work outside your City position.  You have discussed this matter  with the [head] of your department
column7: [  and  he  suggested  you contact the  Board of Ethics.  In a letter of March 22
column9: you  asked  the Board for written advice on whether the Governmental Ethics Ordinance  would limit or prohibit you from  providing pro bono legal  assistance while  you continue to  work for  the  City.  Based on the  facts  you presented
column10: staff  concludes  that  the  Ethics  Ordinance  does  not  prohibit  you  from  providing  this  pro  bono  legal  assistance  while  remaining  employed  in  your  City  position
column11: but  it  does  impose  certain  restrictions  of which  you  should  be  aware.  This  letter  summarizes  the  relevant  facts  and  the  restrictions  the  Ordinance imposes.   In your City position

column14: one of [several bureaus]  in the department.  This  [bureau deals  with  issues  pertinent to]  four  City  departments:  [Department  2]
column22: and  obstructions  of the   public way.   You indicated that you are  interested in doing pro bono legal  work through  [a free legal assistance program for the elderly  ]
column23: a legal assistance project administered by [a lawyers' association   ] .  This  program  provides  free  legal  advice  and representation-for example
column26: and real  estate  documents-to  hospice  patients  in  Chicago  area  hospices  and  to  homebound  elderly.  Attorneys  working  through  this  program  volunteer  their time and services
column27: thus you would not be compensated for your work in   the  program.  You  anticipate  that  you would  primarily handle wills  and  real  estate documents  through the   Case No.  99017.Q  April 7
column29: and you said you would do so outside your City hours
column32: or  days  off.  You  do  not  anticipate  appearing  before  City  agencies
column34: or  appearing before  any other courts or  administrative  bodies
column35: on behalf of clients.  You have  not  yet  made  arrangements  to  work  with  this  or  any  other legal  assistance  program;  however
column36: you  said  you  are  not  currently  interested  in  doing  pro  bono  legal  work  other  than  through  this  program.   Based  on  these  facts  you  presented
column37: staff concludes  that  the  Ordinance  does  not  prohibit  your  proposed pro bono legal work.  However
column38: it does impose certain restrictions on you.   First
column41: contains  several  restrictions.  Section  -090(a)  prohibits you
column43: from  representing or having an economic interest1  in  the representation of any person other than the City in any formal  or informal transaction before  your  own  or  any  other  City  agency  where  the  agency's  action  or  non-action  is  non-ministerial  (i.e.
column44: involves  discretion)  except  in  the  performance  of your  City  employment  duties.  Section  -090(b) prohibits you from having an economic interest in the representation of any person in any  judicial or quasi-judicial proceeding before any administrative agency or court in which the City  is  a party and the person's interest is  adverse to  the  City's.  The  Board has  construed the terms  ""represent""  and  ""representation"" to  apply to  a broad range  of activities  in which one person acts  as  a spokesperson for  another
column47: or submitting written documents to any City personnel or agencies.   Second
column49: you  owe  your  primary  loyalty  to  the  City
column51: ""Fiduciary  Duty.""  This  section  obligates  you  to  use  your  City position  responsibly  and  in  the  best interests of the public

Indoor and Outdoor Cameras- The licensee agrees to install indoor and outdoor cameras for the safety of  patrons  and  community  members.  Such  cameras  shall  be  able  to  record  discernible  images  from  a  minimum distance of 15 feet in  front of and  on the sides of any business entrance. Licensee shall  maintain  such  cameras  and  tapes  or  videos  for  a  minimum  of 72  hours  and  make  such  recordings  immediately  available upon request to any City of Chicago agency.   8. 	  Licensee  shall  post  signage  inside  and  outside  the  store  informing  patrons  not to  loiter either inside  or  outside and shall post signage informing patrons of no loud music.   9. 	 Licensee must clean of all litter interior and exterior of the property on  a daily basis.   10. 	 Licensee must power wash exterior of premises
column35: quarterly.   11. 	 This plan of Operation shall supersede any existing plan of operation at this address.   The  conditions  of this  liquor  license  are  legally  binding  and  may  be  enforced  by  City  of Chicago  enforcement  authorities under Section 4-60-040(h) of the City of Chicago  Municipal Code.  All  other conditions of the license are  governed  by  the  City  of Chicago  Municipal  Code.  Violation  of  the  above  stated  conditions  may  result  in  the  imposition  of a fine  and/or suspension  or revocation  of all  business  licenses  issued  to the  Licensee.  Violations  of  the  above  stated  conditions  may  also  result  in  the  issuance  of cease  and  desist  orders  prohibiting  the  activity  which violates the conditions of the liquor license.   The  conditions of the liquor licenses  issued  pursuant to this plan  of operation  shall  apply to the business  address  and  Licensee and  to all  officers
column38: partners and  direct or indirect owners of the entity of which  is  licensed.  The sale of the Licensee to other persons purchasing the stock of the licensed entity shall  be subject to  the same  conditions  set  forth  in  this  Plan  of Operation.  Any  and  all  potential  new owners  of the licensed  entity  shall be subject to the same conditions set forth in this statement.   It  shall  be  the  duty  of  every  person  conducting
column41: carrying  on  or  managing  the  above­ mentioned business  entity to post this  Liquor License  Plan  of Operation  next to the  Liquor License  certificate in  a  conspicuous place at the business address.   Licensee:  Bond  Drug Company of Illinois
